attributes.title: Assessing the effects of person-schema violations
attributes.description: How do person-schema violations affect changes in representation? Public figures, and violations in the morality and ability dimensions, will be used.

q1.value: Assessing the effects of person-schema violations on representation in the morality and ability dimensions

q3.value: While there has been ample work done in the field of impression updating, very little work has been done in the context of familiar people acting in uncharacteristic or unexpected ways. The purpose of this study is to see how our representations for people who we have strong schemas about - specifically, celebrities and public figures from history - change when presented with information that violates those schemas.

q4.value:
1. Ratings will change more for moral public figures who commit immoral acts than for immoral public figures who commit moral acts. On the flip side, ratings will change more for incompetent public figures who commit competent acts than competent public figures who commit incompetent acts
2. A participant's rating of a public figure will change less in the positive to negative direction when the participant feels an affinity towards them, feels similar to them,  or is familiar with them.
3. Ratings will change more for consequential actions than for inconsequential actions, and this effect will be exacerbated for actions in the more salient direction and mitigated for actions in the less salient direction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This will be a within-subjects study, where the difference in morality and ability ratings for public figures will be measured before and after receiving incongruent information about the figure. The variables are: dimension of violation (morality vs ability), valence of violation (positive to negative vs negative to positive) and consequentiality/severity of the violation (severe vs not severe).

q9.value: Participants will all see the same public figures, but the statements used to evaluate their morality and ability levels will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Piloting subjects to norm stimuli will be recruited via Prolific and paid $6/hour. They will complete surveys using CUMC Qualtrics. In-human testing will include subjects that speak English and are over 18 years old. Subjects will be recruited via typical Columbia recruitment procedures, such as online ads and posters around and near campus. Subjects will be paid $15/hour. The first part of the study (initial ratings) will be completed at home via a Qualtrics survey, and the second part will be completed in-person on Columbia's campus.

q13.value: For each pilot (of which there will be 3), the target sample size is 200 people. For the actual study, the target sample size is 75 people.

q14.value: Currently my rationale is based on time and money, but I intent to conduct a power analysis to confirm my sample size.

question.value:
The main manipulation is the presentation of an action that the public figure has engaged in that violates the normed beliefs about the figure's morality or ability. Here are the variables associated with the violation.
1. The dimension of the violation, either a) morality, or b) ability
2. The valence of the violation, either a) negative information about a positive person, or b) positive information about a negative person
3. The severity of the violation, either a) a severe or consequential violation, or b) an unimportant or inconsequential violation

1. The main measured variable is the difference in morality/ability ratings between before and after seeing the violation. This will be a simple difference score.
2. As predictors, we will also measure, for each public figure:
2a. Familiarity
2b. Similarity
2c. Affinity
2d. Closeness
3. Memory for the violation will also be recorded as a covariate

1. Rating for each figure on either morality or ability will be measured as an average of 3 different statements pertaining to that figure. 
2. Similarity will be measured by asking similar questions about the subject's own morality or ability level, calculating an average, and then a difference between the subject's scores and the public figure's scores. Affinity will also be an average across several questions, most likely 3.

The main statistical model will be a regression model, with difference in trait ratings as the predictor variable. Within-subject predictor variables will be the dimension of the violation (morality vs competence), the valence of the violation (positive to negative vs negative to positive), and the consequentiality of the violation. Between-subject predictor variables will be the amount of liking, familiarity, and similarity for each public figure.

q20.value: Valence, direction, and consequentiality will be effect coded, and ratings will be mean-centered.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 for all regression models, but will also assess the results holistically and will not be tied to a hard cut-off.

attributes.title: Authoritarianism and Social Dominance Orientation amongst ni-Vanuatu horticulturalists

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value:
Authoritarianism and Social Dominance Orientation amongst ni-Vanuatu horticulturalists:
Validation of political ideology constructs, links between family and nation politics, and effects of market integration on political opinion

other.value: After the confirmatory analysis, we may run some exploratory analyses. For example, it would be interesting to know how family-level SDO scores change with economic integration.

sample.value: The sample size numbers 162 individuals. This includes 39 from Mele on Efate, 48 from southeast Tanna, 30 from south Pentecost, and 45 from Vetuboso on Vanua Lava. We will keep to the rule-of-thumb that there should be at least 10 data points for each parameter in the model (Concato, Peduzzi, Holford, & Feinstein, 1995; Vittinghoff & McCulloch, 2007).

analyses.value:
The ordinal nature of the questionnaire items will be specified within the models used for analysis. Since some columns contain missing values (the column with the highest number being participant age, with 3 out of 162), we will try to use case-wise maximum likelihood estimation to replace the values (i.e., with the assumption that the missingness of these values is not related to other features of the data).
For question 1 we will attempt to use confirmatory factor analysis to investigate correlations between survey items. We will start with a model that includes all of the factors we have predictions about (that is, ‘Authoritarianism’, ‘SDO’, ‘Authoritarianism family’, ‘Authoritarianism nation’, ‘SDO family’, ‘SDO nation’, ‘pro-trait wording’, ‘con-trait wording’). We will then begin to remove each of the factors in different models and compare model fits. This will enable us to see whether the survey questions behaved as expected in the novel context. It may become impractical to use this approach given the small sample size relative to the number of parameters included in the models, so if the models do not converge we will adopt alternative modelling techniques to answer the same question.
For questions 2 and 3, we will endeavor to use structural equation modelling. Again, there is the possibility that these models will not converge. If this is the case, we will use other means of testing the same hypotheses. For question 2, we will use the latent variables for ‘Authoritarianism family’ and ‘SDO family’ to predict the latent variables for ‘Authoritarianism nation’ and ‘SDO nation’, respectively. We will examine whether the predictive strength of family-level Authoritarianism and SDO is each retained when accounting for the other. We will examine whether the effect of family-level Authoritarianism and SDO on the nation-level latent variables is dependent on whether the participant said that national-level government was important for their life (as expected from Stellmacher & Petzel, 2005). After answering these predictions, we will check to see if the resulting model’s effects are robust to controls for several supplementary variables. These supplementary variables will be: participant age, sex, education level, whether they have employment (yes/no), and site of data collection (Mele village on Efate, southeast Tanna, south Pentecost, and Vetuboso on Vanua Lava). We will run models controlling for each independently and then a model controlling for all together.
For question 3 we will first estimate the effects of an individual-level variable for employment on SDO (family and nation) and Authoritarianism (family and nation) scores using structural equation modelling. While, as explained above, we do not have predictions for the effect of economic integration on family-level SDO, we will include the family level in the model for the purpose of exploratory analysis. We will then run versions of this model while controlling for other variables: whether data collection was rural or peri-urban (i.e. if it was in Mele), participant age, sex, and schooling year. We will then run similar analyses but where the predictor variable will be binary: whether data collection was in peri-urban Mele or a rural community. Again we will run a model with this predictor’s effects on family- and nation-level SDO and on family- and nation-level Authoritarianism, and after, the same model but controlling for the other variables both separately and together (these variables being: whether the participant had employment, participant age, sex, and education level).

outliers.value: Two cases will be excluded from the dataset to give the 162-strong sample size. One case will be excluded because it was a trial run after which the interview technique was altered. Another will be excluded because a wife began answering the survey and then her husband started answering for her. Aside from these two cases, outliers will not be excluded from analyses. Only if we become unable to impute missing data in our analyses will we have to remove cases with missing data.

dependent.value: The dependent variables will be Likert scale responses of agreement or disagreement, where 1 is strong disagreement and 6 strong agreement. Four Social Dominance Orientation questions were adapted from Ho et al.'s (2015) scale and six Authoritarianism questions were adapted from Stellmacher and Petzel's (2005) scale. The same SDO and Authoritarianism questions were adapted to two levels of social organisation: family and nation, so participants were asked eight SDO questions twelve Authoritarianism questions in total. Half of the questions were worded pro-trait such that agreement with the question implied a high score in the trait, while half of the questions were worded con-trait such that agreement with the question implied a low score for the trait. Interviews were conducted in Bislama.

conditions.value: There are no separate conditions which participants were assigned to. Each participant was asked the same questions.

hypothesis.value: The study has three questions. 1) Among ni-Vanuatu participants, do questions from the SDO and Authoritarianism questionnaires, respectively, correlate with each other more than they do with questions from the other questionnaires? If SDO and Authoritarianism represent independent axes of political ideology, we should find that participants answers are more consistent within the same questionnaire than between the SDO and Authoritarianism questionnaires. 2) Do participants’ SDO and Authoritarianism scores with respect to the family unit of social organisation predict SDO and Authoritarianism scores with respect to the nation unit of social organisation? If individuals have stable dispositions for each axis, then there should be a predictive relationship between their answers at the family level and nation level. 3) Is increased dependence on wage labour associated with increased SDO and reduced Authoritarianism scores? If exposure to competitive and unequal environments leads to higher SDO, increased dependence on wage labour should be associated with higher SDO, and if dependence on a social group leads to Authoritarianism then increased dependence on wage labour should be associated with lower Authoritarianism. We do not, however, make predictions about changes in family-level SDO as we lack specific literature about the effects of economic integration on hierarchies within the family.

If SDO and Authoritarianism represent independent axes of political ideology, we should find that participants answers are more consistent within the same questionnaire than between the SDO and Authoritarianism questionnaires. 2) Do participants’ SDO and Authoritarianism scores with respect to the family unit of social organisation predict SDO and Authoritarianism scores with respect to the nation unit of social organisation? We do not, however, make predictions about changes in family-level SDO as we lack specific literature about the effects of economic integration on hierarchies within the family.

attributes.title: A Randomized, Controlled Experiment of the Effect of a Fast Food Environment on Food Expectancies

summary.value:
In contrast to what the original preregistration states, the Yale Food Addiction Scale was not administered in the study. The decision to remove the Yale Food Addiction Scale from the study procedure was made (1) to shorten the length of the study, and (2) because study investigators thought that there would be low rates of endorsement of food addiction symptoms in a sample drawn from the UM Department of Psychology’s SONA participant pool. There was a miscommunication among study investigators regarding this change, which resulted in the error in the preregistration. 

Update on Sample Size: The study was completed on Dec. 4th, 2019. We collected data from 203 participants from the UM Department of Psychology’s SONA participant pool. As per the original preregistration, we will exclude participants due to researcher error (e.g., protocol executed in incorrect order) and/or participant ineligibility (e.g., participants arrives to study intoxicated) in primary analysis. This includes 1 participant who during study debriefing requested that their data would be destroyed, 1 participant who was not administered the Anticipated Effects of Food Scale (but instead accidentally administered other questionnaires twice), and 1 participant who verbally admitted that they were "very high" during the study.

registration_responses.summary:
In contrast to what the original preregistration states, the Yale Food Addiction Scale was not administered in the study. The decision to remove the Yale Food Addiction Scale from the study procedure was made (1) to shorten the length of the study, and (2) because study investigators thought that there would be low rates of endorsement of food addiction symptoms in a sample drawn from the UM Department of Psychology’s SONA participant pool. There was a miscommunication among study investigators regarding this change, which resulted in the error in the preregistration. 

Update on Sample Size: The study was completed on Dec. 4th, 2019. We collected data from 203 participants from the UM Department of Psychology’s SONA participant pool. As per the original preregistration, we will exclude participants due to researcher error (e.g., protocol executed in incorrect order) and/or participant ineligibility (e.g., participants arrives to study intoxicated) in primary analysis. This includes 1 participant who during study debriefing requested that their data would be destroyed, 1 participant who was not administered the Anticipated Effects of Food Scale (but instead accidentally administered other questionnaires twice), and 1 participant who verbally admitted that they were "very high" during the study.

attributes.title: How Perceptions of Inequality and Opportunity Affect Policy Preferences

q1.value: How Perceptions of Inequality and Opportunity Affect Policy Preferences

q3.value:
Research has indicated that both perceptions of inequality and perceptions of opportunity could be having an effect on people’s policy preferences. No study has ever utilized a research design that could precisely identify the direct and interaction effects associated with perceptions of inequality on the one hand and perceptions of opportunity on the other. In other words, we do not know for sure which of these two factors has a bigger impact in driving policy preferences and by how much, neither do we know how these factors jointly shape such preferences. Accordingly, this study asks the following research questions:

1. How does perceptions of inequality influence people’s policy preferences?
2. How does perceptions of opportunity influence people’s policy preferences?
3. Does perceptions of inequality or opportunity have a larger influence on people’s policy preferences?
4. How do perceptions of inequality and opportunity jointly influence people’s policy preferences?

Understanding the relative importance of inequality and opportunity has important implications for scholars and policymakers. For example, if people care about opportunity, then in a democratic system, policies for reducing inequality are most likely to be adopted if they can be framed in terms of equalizing opportunity as opposed to equalizing outcomes. On the other hand, if inequality itself is the larger concern, then policies for reducing inequality through equalizing outcomes may be more compelling.

q4.value:
1. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies when economic inequality is perceived to be high.
2. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies when economic opportunity is perceived to be low. 
3. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies under low opportunity, low inequality compared to high opportunity, high inequality.
4. The difference in support for redistributive policies between low and high opportunity when inequality is high will be bigger than the difference between low and high opportunity when inequality is low.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q9.value: Each respondent will be randomly assigned to one of the four experimental conditions, making sure that the conditions get presented evenly.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I have implemented the survey experiment using Qualtrics, which UC Berkeley has a free license for. Data collection will take place on the Lucid platform, which will include a link to the survey experiment. The study will require respondents to be US residents and 18 or older.

q14.value: I determined my sample size using standard procedures for calculating power in 2x2 factorial designs. The sample size allows me to have 90% power to be able to detect a small interaction effect in 2-way ANOVA.

question.value: I will manipulate {high perceived inequality, low perceived inequality} and {high perceived opportunity, low perceived opportunity} for a 2x2 set of possible experimental conditions. Each participant will be independently randomly assigned to one of the 4 possible conditions.

My rectangular dataset will have one row for each respondent; the columns will be:

consent: binary
economy_answer: categorical (3 categories)
teen_jobs_answer: categorical (3)
inequality_condition: binary
opportunity_condition: binary
inequality_answer: categorical (3)
opportunity_answer: categorical (3)
individual_effort_or_luck: binary
eq_opportunity_or_outcomes: binary
role_of_government: ordinal (5)
ineq_serious_problem: ordinal (5)
how_to_fix_ineq: rank (5)
how_to_fix_ineq_text: text
high_earners_deserve: ordinal (3)
increase_taxes_on_millionares: ordinal (3)
increase_estate_tax: ordinal (3)
increase_min_wage: ordinal (3)
increase_aid_to_poor: ordinal (5)
increase_food_stamps: ordinal (5)
support_entrepreneurs: binary
support_housing: binary
gap_btw_rich_and_poor_increasing: binary
childen_have_better_chances: binary
is_us_resident: binary
state: categorical (50+)
gender: categorical (3)
age: text
marital_status: binary
has_children: binary
race: categorical (5)
education: ordinal (9)
employment_status: categorical (6)
income: ordinal (12)
intergen_mobility: ordinal (5)
intragen_mobility: ordinal (5)
liberal_vs_conservative: ordinal (5)
democrat_vs_republican: categorical (4)

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ epsilon

q21.value: I’ll be making inferences using standard two tailed tests for each of my estimates. I’ll use the conventional threshold of alpha = 0.05. Adjustments will be made for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: I’ll only use results from respondents who successfully finish the entirety of the survey.

q24.value:
There is also evidence in the literature that the perception effects are significantly moderated by political ideology (e.g., right-wing vs. left-wing). Therefore, an additional research question is:

* How does political ideology moderate the influence of inequality and opportunity perceptions on policy preferences?

The hypotheses corresponding to this research question are:

* Left-wing respondents will be more supportive of redistributive policies compared to right-wing respondents.
* The perception effects described in Hypotheses 1 and 2 will be larger for left-wing respondents.

The statistical model here will be: 

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Political orientation 
+ beta_5 * Inequality * Political orientation 
+ beta_6 * Opportunity * Political orientation 
+ beta_7 * Inequality * Opportunity * Political orientation 
+ epsilon

Similarly, I will also be checking how reported inter- and intra-generational mobility influence the outcomes.

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Inter-generational mobility
(+ beta_5 * Income)
+ epsilon

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Intra-generational mobility
(+ beta_5 * Income)
+ epsilon

registration_responses.q1: How Perceptions of Inequality and Opportunity Affect Policy Preferences
registration_responses.q3:
Research has indicated that both perceptions of inequality and perceptions of opportunity could be having an effect on people’s policy preferences. No study has ever utilized a research design that could precisely identify the direct and interaction effects associated with perceptions of inequality on the one hand and perceptions of opportunity on the other. In other words, we do not know for sure which of these two factors has a bigger impact in driving policy preferences and by how much, neither do we know how these factors jointly shape such preferences. Accordingly, this study asks the following research questions:

1. How does perceptions of inequality influence people’s policy preferences?
2. How does perceptions of opportunity influence people’s policy preferences?
3. Does perceptions of inequality or opportunity have a larger influence on people’s policy preferences?
4. How do perceptions of inequality and opportunity jointly influence people’s policy preferences?

Understanding the relative importance of inequality and opportunity has important implications for scholars and policymakers. For example, if people care about opportunity, then in a democratic system, policies for reducing inequality are most likely to be adopted if they can be framed in terms of equalizing opportunity as opposed to equalizing outcomes. On the other hand, if inequality itself is the larger concern, then policies for reducing inequality through equalizing outcomes may be more compelling.
registration_responses.q4:
1. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies when economic inequality is perceived to be high.
2. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies when economic opportunity is perceived to be low. 
3. People will be more supportive of redistributive policies under low opportunity, low inequality compared to high opportunity, high inequality.
4. The difference in support for redistributive policies between low and high opportunity when inequality is high will be bigger than the difference between low and high opportunity when inequality is low.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Each respondent will be randomly assigned to one of the four experimental conditions, making sure that the conditions get presented evenly.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q14: I determined my sample size using standard procedures for calculating power in 2x2 factorial designs. The sample size allows me to have 90% power to be able to detect a small interaction effect in 2-way ANOVA.
registration_responses.q21: I’ll be making inferences using standard two tailed tests for each of my estimates. I’ll use the conventional threshold of alpha = 0.05. Adjustments will be made for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q22: I’ll only use results from respondents who successfully finish the entirety of the survey.
registration_responses.q24:
There is also evidence in the literature that the perception effects are significantly moderated by political ideology (e.g., right-wing vs. left-wing). Therefore, an additional research question is:

* How does political ideology moderate the influence of inequality and opportunity perceptions on policy preferences?

The hypotheses corresponding to this research question are:

* Left-wing respondents will be more supportive of redistributive policies compared to right-wing respondents.
* The perception effects described in Hypotheses 1 and 2 will be larger for left-wing respondents.

The statistical model here will be: 

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Political orientation 
+ beta_5 * Inequality * Political orientation 
+ beta_6 * Opportunity * Political orientation 
+ beta_7 * Inequality * Opportunity * Political orientation 
+ epsilon

Similarly, I will also be checking how reported inter- and intra-generational mobility influence the outcomes.

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Inter-generational mobility
(+ beta_5 * Income)
+ epsilon

Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ beta_4 * Intra-generational mobility
(+ beta_5 * Income)
+ epsilon
registration_responses.q8.question: 2x2 factorial between-subjects design.
registration_responses.q12.question: I have implemented the survey experiment using Qualtrics, which UC Berkeley has a free license for. Data collection will take place on the Lucid platform, which will include a link to the survey experiment. The study will require respondents to be US residents and 18 or older.
registration_responses.q16.question: I will manipulate {high perceived inequality, low perceived inequality} and {high perceived opportunity, low perceived opportunity} for a 2x2 set of possible experimental conditions. Each participant will be independently randomly assigned to one of the 4 possible conditions.
registration_responses.q17.question:
My rectangular dataset will have one row for each respondent; the columns will be:

consent: binary
economy_answer: categorical (3 categories)
teen_jobs_answer: categorical (3)
inequality_condition: binary
opportunity_condition: binary
inequality_answer: categorical (3)
opportunity_answer: categorical (3)
individual_effort_or_luck: binary
eq_opportunity_or_outcomes: binary
role_of_government: ordinal (5)
ineq_serious_problem: ordinal (5)
how_to_fix_ineq: rank (5)
how_to_fix_ineq_text: text
high_earners_deserve: ordinal (3)
increase_taxes_on_millionares: ordinal (3)
increase_estate_tax: ordinal (3)
increase_min_wage: ordinal (3)
increase_aid_to_poor: ordinal (5)
increase_food_stamps: ordinal (5)
support_entrepreneurs: binary
support_housing: binary
gap_btw_rich_and_poor_increasing: binary
childen_have_better_chances: binary
is_us_resident: binary
state: categorical (50+)
gender: categorical (3)
age: text
marital_status: binary
has_children: binary
race: categorical (5)
education: ordinal (9)
employment_status: categorical (6)
income: ordinal (12)
intergen_mobility: ordinal (5)
intragen_mobility: ordinal (5)
liberal_vs_conservative: ordinal (5)
democrat_vs_republican: categorical (4)
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
Support for redistribution 
= alpha 
+ beta_1 * Inequality 
+ beta_2 * Opportunity 
+ beta_3 * Inequality * Opportunity 
+ epsilon

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We are collecting data on participant race, gender, belief in a just world, political orientation, and general estimates of wealth inequality. We will examine correlations with these measures to explore whether estimates map onto prior associations observed in our past research.  This work will be largely confirmatory as we expect associations to look as we reported in our 2017 and 2019 papers.

sample.value: We will collect 200 people per condition for a total of 2000 respondents in the study. We'll field the survey on MTurk for 2200 participants in case there is some unequal assignment to condition.

analyses.value:
The primary analysis of interest is to compare each Black-White wealth equality estimate to the most updated federal data on the actual wealth gap, which indicates that Black Americans have about $10.16 for every $100 of wealth held by White Americans. We will conduct a series of one sample t-tests comparing mean estimates of the gap with this federal marker (alpha level will be p < .05). We predict that all conditions will produce overestimates of Black-White wealth equality.

Beyond this central prediction, we will conduct a one-way analysis of variance, followed by Fisher's LSD to determine condition differences in estimates of Black-White wealth equality (alpha level will be p < .05). This will be largely exploratory given we are not yet sure which modes of estimation will produce higher overestimates and which will produce more accuracy.

outliers.value: Given the brevity of this survey, we will not exclude responses from this survey,

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is participant estimates of current Black wealth relative to White wealth. The question wording differs by condition but the DV is the same for each condition, which is the extent that estimates differ from the actual Black-White wealth gap.

conditions.value:
We have 10 experimental conditions, each of which represents a slightly different way of asking about Black-White wealth equality. They are (see the survey attached):
-The published way using 0-200 scale where White families have $100, estimating Black wealth.
-Same as the published way but calling families typical v. average
-Same as the published way but refers to a person instead of families
-Same as the published way, but asking about past Black-White wealth equality too.
-Same as the published way, but informing participants about past Black-White wealth equality.
-Same as the published way but providing a $100 bonus for the right answer
-Same as the published way, but capping estimates at $0-$100 (equality)
-Same as the published way but using an open ended item v. a scale.
-Same as the open ended item, but framing the question around Black families with $100 in wealth and asking to estimate White wealth.
-Same question as the published way, but using pictures of gold coins v. numbers.

hypothesis.value: We expect respondents to overestimate black-white wealth equality independent of subtle changes in framing of the question responses.

attributes.title: Framing Racial Inequality Estimates
attributes.description: In this project our goal is to see if subtle framing differences in how we ask about racial inequality between black and white americans elicits accuracy in perceptions of the black-white wealth gap.

attributes.title: Self Determination Theory Interventions for Health Behavior Change

summary.value:
We conducted a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials to promote health
behavior change based on self-determination theory (SDT). The review aimed to (a) quantify the impact of SDT interventions on health behaviors, (b) test mediation by theoretically specified variables (autonomous motivation and perceived competence), and (c) identify moderators of intervention effectiveness.  The sample-weighted average effect size for SDT
interventions was d+ = .23, and there were significant effects for physical activity, sedentary
behavior, diet, alcohol consumption, and smoking cessation (.16 ≥ d+ ≥ .29). Effect sizes
exhibited both publication bias and small sample bias but remained significantly different from zero, albeit of smaller magnitude, after correction for bias (d+ ≥ .15).

registration_responses.summary:
We conducted a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials to promote health
behavior change based on self-determination theory (SDT). The review aimed to (a) quantify the impact of SDT interventions on health behaviors, (b) test mediation by theoretically specified variables (autonomous motivation and perceived competence), and (c) identify moderators of intervention effectiveness.  The sample-weighted average effect size for SDT
interventions was d+ = .23, and there were significant effects for physical activity, sedentary
behavior, diet, alcohol consumption, and smoking cessation (.16 ≥ d+ ≥ .29). Effect sizes
exhibited both publication bias and small sample bias but remained significantly different from zero, albeit of smaller magnitude, after correction for bias (d+ ≥ .15).

attributes.title: Mistakes were made: Episodic retrieval of erroneous responses
attributes.description: In this study we investigated processes of stimulus-response binding and retrieval for erroneous responses. Are mistakes stored and retrieved from memory, like correct responses, leading to a perpetuation of erroneous behavior? Or do people take into account that an error was made, storing and retrieving only correct or corrected responses? Two experiments were designed to assess SR binding and retrieval effects in a sequential prime/probe design using a colour classification task, with an orthogonal variation of response relation (colour repetition vs. change) and stimulus relation (word repetition vs. change). Experiment 1 (n=83) measured SR binding and retrieval for errors that occurred under time pressure (chance errors), while Experiment 2 (n=81) required participants to deliberately respond erroneously (instructed errors) in some of the trials. We found standard SR binding effects following accurate responses in the prime in both experiments. However, no significant SR binding effects were obtained in trials following erroneous prime responses, indicating either that errors are not bound and/or retrieved from memory, or that retrieval of both erroneous and corrected responses might have neutralized each other.

q1.value: Mistakes were made: Episodic retrieval of erroneous responses

q3.value: In this study we investigate processes of stimulus-response binding and retrieval for erroneous responses. Are mistakes stored and retrieved from memory, like correct responses, leading to a perpetuation of erroneous behaviour? Or do people take into account that an error was made, storing and retrieving only correct or corrected responses? Or, are there other mechanisms at play? This experiment is designed to assess SR binding and retrieval effects in a sequential prime/probe design using a colour classification task, with an orthogonal variation of response relation (colour repetition vs. change) and stimulus relation (word repetition vs. change). We compare SR binding and retrieval for correct responses and for errors that occur under time pressure (chance errors) in a student sample (n=60).

q4.value:
1) We predict standard SR binding effects following accurate responses in the prime trials, i.e. facilitation effects of stimulus repetition in reaction time and accuracy for probe trials with response repetition, and interference effects for response changes.

2) For trials following an error in the prime, we test the following theories:
2a) No Retrieval after error (“success-based retrieval”): reflected by a null effect owing to previous incorrect response being not stored in episodic memory since this theory predicts that only successful information is stored.
2b) Dual Process account: reflected by a null effect owing to both, executed erroneous response and non-executed correct response being recalled. This leads to both processes cancelling each other out, explaining the null effect. To distinguish this account from the success-based retrieval account, we predict that particularly in trials where neither the erroneous nor the correct response is relevant to the stimulus that is presented in the probe (a third colour), we expect to see higher interference effects since both responses are recalled, and their irrelevance to the presented stimulus should lead to higher reaction times.
2c) Only the executed response is retrieved in all instances, regardless of whether it is correct or incorrect (unconditional response retrieval): reflected by facilitation for probe trials where response repetition is the correct response (colour repetition), and interference for trials where the colour changes in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).
2d) Only the rule is retrieved in all instances (target retrieval account): reflected by facilitation for colour repetitions in the probe, and interference for colour change in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within subjects design with 3 nested factors: Distractor relation (word repetition vs. word change), prime status (correct response vs. error), response relation (repetition vs. change for correct prime responses; repetition of executed erroneous response vs. repetition of  to-be-executed response vs. response change), resulting in a 2 x 2 design within the correct prime response condition, and a 2 x 3 design within the erroneous prime response condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Primarily, students of Friedrich Schiller University, Jena will be recruited for participation in this study. Participants will be recruited using posters and flyers displayed across the university campus, as well as through personal contacts. Participants are paid at the rate of Eur 8 per hour of their time, along with an additional bar of chocolate at the end of the experiment to incentivise completing the task by abiding to all the instructions. There are no strict eligibility criteria. We will try to balance participants for age and gender. Roughly, we aim to complete data collection in 2 weeks, followed by 6-8 weeks on data analysis and interpretation. Following this, the results will be used for dissemination and science communication.

q13.value: For a moderate effect size, a sample size of 56 would be needed according to an a-priori power-analysis done with G*Power (Version 3.1.9.4).

q14.value: We aim to test roughly 60 participants, taking into consideration outliers and unusable data.

question.value:
We will be studying the following variables:
Distractor relation: distractor repetition vs. distractor change
Prime response status: correct response in the prime vs. erroneous response in the prime
Response relation: response repetition vs. response change within the correct prime response condition; repetition of the executed response vs. repetition of the to-be-executed response vs. different response in the incorrect prime response condition.

We aim to measure reaction time and accuracy. More precisely, we are interested in error rate, and how errors impact performance.
For this, we will be using a sequential prime-probe design, and evaluating participants' performance (RT and error rate) on probe trials after they made an error in the prime compared to their performance (RT and error rate) after a correct response on the prime
Repeated measures ANOVAs will be calculated for mean reaction times, mean error rates, and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score [IES=RT/ACC] for each condition of the within subjects design.

Since all hypotheses rest on error rates and reaction times, the same statistical analyses will be used:
Repeated measures ANOVAs for mean reaction times, mean error rates and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score), with repeated measures on the three within subjects factors of the design

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypotheses were correct.

q22.value: Participants with extreme error rates indicating random responding on most of the trials will be rejected from analyses. For RT analyses, we will exclude outlier responses according to Tukey’s outlier criterion (1,5 interquartile ranges above the third quartile).

q23.value: If the participant terminates the experiment before completion, this will be rejected as missing data. Other factors like being under the influence of substances, or random responding will also lead to exclusion of data.

q25.value: This study is based on experiments conducted by bachelor students at the Department of General Psychology, 2 in the Institute for Psychology, Jena in September 2019. The current study is a follow up experiment that aims to test hypotheses that were generated on the basis of the previous data. While still a colour categorisation task, our experiment was altered to 3 colours and 3 response keys rather than 4 colours and 2 response keys. The core question, however, remains the same - what is stored and retrieved after an error is made? The null effect in the previous data led to a new series of hypotheses to interpret the data, which are now being tested.

registration_responses.q3: In this study we investigate processes of stimulus-response binding and retrieval for erroneous responses. Are mistakes stored and retrieved from memory, like correct responses, leading to a perpetuation of erroneous behaviour? Or do people take into account that an error was made, storing and retrieving only correct or corrected responses? Or, are there other mechanisms at play? This experiment is designed to assess SR binding and retrieval effects in a sequential prime/probe design using a colour classification task, with an orthogonal variation of response relation (colour repetition vs. change) and stimulus relation (word repetition vs. change). We compare SR binding and retrieval for correct responses and for errors that occur under time pressure (chance errors) in a student sample (n=60).
registration_responses.q4:
1) We predict standard SR binding effects following accurate responses in the prime trials, i.e. facilitation effects of stimulus repetition in reaction time and accuracy for probe trials with response repetition, and interference effects for response changes.

2) For trials following an error in the prime, we test the following theories:
2a) No Retrieval after error (“success-based retrieval”): reflected by a null effect owing to previous incorrect response being not stored in episodic memory since this theory predicts that only successful information is stored.
2b) Dual Process account: reflected by a null effect owing to both, executed erroneous response and non-executed correct response being recalled. This leads to both processes cancelling each other out, explaining the null effect. To distinguish this account from the success-based retrieval account, we predict that particularly in trials where neither the erroneous nor the correct response is relevant to the stimulus that is presented in the probe (a third colour), we expect to see higher interference effects since both responses are recalled, and their irrelevance to the presented stimulus should lead to higher reaction times.
2c) Only the executed response is retrieved in all instances, regardless of whether it is correct or incorrect (unconditional response retrieval): reflected by facilitation for probe trials where response repetition is the correct response (colour repetition), and interference for trials where the colour changes in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).
2d) Only the rule is retrieved in all instances (target retrieval account): reflected by facilitation for colour repetitions in the probe, and interference for colour change in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Belief in school meritocracy and self-esteem (DISESTEEM)
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
IV 1: Performance condition with 2 modalities (success vs. failure). Between subject variable. 
IV2 (continuous variable): Mean-centered BSM (from 1: very low to 7: very high).  
Covariate: Perception of mean academic abilities and GPA & gender.

question2b.value:
DV1: self-esteem1 (from 1: very low to 7: very high)
DV2: Disengagement, with three subscales: devaluing, discounting and general disengagement (from 1: very low to 7: very high)
DV3: self-esteem2 (from 1: very low to 7: very high)

question3b.value: Covariate: Perception of mean academic abilities and GPA & gender.

question10b.value: A file with the complete material (manipulations, scales,...) is attached.

question4b.value: The present study will be conducted on American students. Indeed, American individuals have been identified as associating quite strongly performance to self-esteem (Zhang & Cross, 2011, see also Ross & Wang, 20109). Thus, we believe our manipulation should be quite effective on American participants.

question5b.value: This will be an online study: 500 participants will be recruited within an online professional platform and will be paid $1 in exchange for their participation.

question6b.value: No study has used the present manipulation in interaction with BSM so far. However, as many experiments in social psychology, we expect the interaction effect to be quite small in size (etap² =.02). Gpower analysis indicate that 387 participants are required to have 80% chances to detect an effect of such a size. However, we use an online platform and consequently, we may loose participants because of missing data or erroneous answers to the open-ended question. Thus, we target a sample of 500 participants.

question8b.value: Two attention check items have been included in the questionnaire ("filter1" and "filter2"). Participants who fail to answer these two check items will be removed from the analyses.  In addition, the manipulation will be an imagery manipulation: Participants will be asked write down few lines describing what they imagine. Participants who will provide absurd or irrelevant answers to this open-ended question will be removed from the analyses.

question1a.value:
The goal of the present research is to examine whether belief in school meritocracy (BSM) increases or decreases the strength of the link between performance, self-esteem and psychological disengagement. Indeed, compared to situations of success, situations of failure are likely to have a negative impact on self-esteem and a positive impact on disengagement (a strategy often used to protect a threatened self-esteem). In the present research, BSM is tested as a moderator of this effect. 
Indeed, literature may lead to two alternative hypotheses regarding the moderating effect of BSM on the effect of performance condition (success/failure) on self-esteem and disengagement. 

On the one hand, valuing efforts and hard work should be associated with a growth-mindset and should therefore favour persistence in the event of failure or difficulty (Autin & Croizet, 2012; Dweck, 1992, 1999; Mueller & Dweck, 1998). Moreover, believing in mobility is a factor that has been shown to maintain the motivation of first generation students at University (Browman, Destin, Carswelld, & Svobodab, 2017).
-->This theoretical approach leads to the prediction that BSM should protect self-esteem in the event of failure. Thus, an increase in BSM should reduce the effect of performance condition (success vs. difficulties) on self-esteem and disengagement. 

On the other hand, other research has shown that in meritocratic environments, performance is perceived as a reliable indicator of ability (Trautwein, Lüdtke, Köller, & Baumert, 2006), individuals develop self-perceptions that are consistent with the place their group occupies in the hierarchy (McCoy & Major, 2007; Fraser & Kick, 2000; Jost, 2001), which may widen the SES achievement gap (Darnon, Wiederkehr, Dompnier & Martinot, 2017). 
-->This theoretical approach leads to the prediction that BSM should make individuals particularly vulnerable to failure. Thus, an increase in BSM should increase the effect of performance condition (success vs. difficulties) on self-esteem and disengagement. 

The two theoretical approaches lead to predicting a 2-way interaction between performance and BSM but in opposite directions. The goal of the present research is to test these two alternative hypotheses.

question2a.value:
HYP.A1: The negative effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on self-esteem should decrease with BSM. 
HYP.A2: The positive effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on disengagement should decrease with BSM.

HYP.B1: The negative effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on self-esteem should increase with BSM. 
HYP.B2: The positive effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on disengagement should increase with BSM.

question3a.value: The manipulation will be an imagery manipulation, similar to that used by Ruvollo & Markus (1996): Participants will be asked to imagine themselves in the future, either in a success or in a failure situation, and to write down a paragraph describing what they imagine. Participants who will provide absurd or irrelevant answers to this open-ended question will be removed from the analyses.

question1c.value:
Our regression model includes mean-centered BSM, perf condition (success 0,5 vs. failure -0,5) and their interaction. 
Mean-centered perceived academic level and gender will be entered in the analyses as covariates. Their interactions with the IV will also be entered in the analyses when appropriate (Yzerbyt et al., 2004).

This model will be regressed on self-esteem 1, disengagement and self-esteem 2.

In supplementary analyses, social class (measure by generational status: first generation vs. continuing generation students) will be included as another predictor of the DVs. Indeed, it seems reasonable to argue that low SES participants might be particularly sensitive to the performance manipulation and meritocratic believes. Thus, the above effect could be stronger for first-generation students than for continuing generation students. 
In addition, as developed above, disengagement may be used as a strategy to restore a positive self-esteem. Thus, in supplementary analyses, the moment of the self-esteem measure will be entered in the analyses as a within-subject variable. 

Two interactions involving this within-subject variable are expected: 
-	First, an interaction between condition and moment of the measure should indicate that the condition affected SE1 but not SE2. 
-	Second, previous research has shown that lower social class (first generation) students usually have a poorer academic self-esteem than higher social class students (continuing generation) students. Thus, a main effect of social class on self-esteem should appear on SE1, but should no longer appear on SE2, because students will be provided with the opportunity to disengage between the two measures. 
These interaction hypotheses will be tested in further analyses.

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
HYP.A1: The negative effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on self-esteem should decrease with BSM. 
HYP.A2: The positive effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on disengagement should decrease with BSM.

HYP.B1: The negative effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on self-esteem should increase with BSM. 
HYP.B2: The positive effect of the imagery condition (success vs. failure) on disengagement should increase with BSM.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: The manipulation will be an imagery manipulation, similar to that used by Ruvollo & Markus (1996): Participants will be asked to imagine themselves in the future, either in a success or in a failure situation, and to write down a paragraph describing what they imagine. Participants who will provide absurd or irrelevant answers to this open-ended question will be removed from the analyses.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
IV 1: Performance condition with 2 modalities (success vs. failure). Between subject variable. 
IV2 (continuous variable): Mean-centered BSM (from 1: very low to 7: very high).  
Covariate: Perception of mean academic abilities and GPA & gender.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
DV1: self-esteem1 (from 1: very low to 7: very high)
DV2: Disengagement, with three subscales: devaluing, discounting and general disengagement (from 1: very low to 7: very high)
DV3: self-esteem2 (from 1: very low to 7: very high)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: Covariate: Perception of mean academic abilities and GPA & gender.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: A file with the complete material (manipulations, scales,...) is attached.
